item.title: Cronos: The New Dawn Release Date Explained—Start Times & Release Date Confirmed
item.content:encoded:
We’re into the period of the year where big releases are coming thick and fast, with Cronos: The New Dawn included in that window, with a release date that is rapidly approaching.

A terrifying new trailer at Gamescom has ignited additional excitement ahead of release, and gamers around the world don’t have too much longer to wait until enjoying the apocalyptic adventure can begin.

If you’re looking to circle the release of Cronos: The New Dawn in your calendar, we’ve got the release date details and the exact time you can start playing.

When is Cronos: The New Dawn Coming Out?

September 5 is the official release date for Cronos: The New Dawn, which will be available on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, PC, and Nintendo Switch 2.

The release date is locked in and is rapidly approaching, so there shouldn’t be any delays, and it won’t be long until your survival adventure begins.

With exploration in a brutal future, combined with travel to 1980s Poland to extract key people, the adventure through the timestream looks set to be one of the biggest games launching in this release period.

Cronos: The New Dawn Start Times

Cronos: The New Dawn will be available to play from 7am PT, with the start time being confirmed by store listings of the title.

The PlayStation Store page details exactly when you can jump into Cronos: The New Dawn, which, unlike many other titles, has a global release window. This means that everyone around the world can begin at exactly the same time, rather than the staggered launch adopted by other titles.

In the table below, we’ve highlighted the precise release times for major time zones across the world to make for easier viewing. Remember, though, these have not been confirmed officially and are subject to change.

item.title: Rumors Of The Next Nintendo Direct Pick Up Steam
item.content:encoded:
Rumors are circling regarding the next Nintendo Direct event. According to multiple reports, Nintendo is planning to hold its next direct showcase sometime in September.

According to SwitchForce, who has been accurate with Nintendo information in the past, the next direct appears to be planned for September 12.

“Nintendo tried to phone in an emergency about the missing Switch 2 games, but they accidentally dialed 912,” they said.

It’s not just SwitchForce claiming a direct is coming. While not confirming the date, VGC did say that its own sources tell them that a mid-September Nintendo Direct is planned.

As far as what this upcoming direct would cover, that’s currently unknown. There has been speculation that it will focus on Metroid Prime 4: Beyond, especially with it recently receiving an ESRB rating. The game is also scheduled to release sometime this year, and with only four months left in the year, signs point to it being time to give fans a deeper dive into the game.

item.title: Borderlands 4 Release Date Explained—Start Times & Release Date Confirmed
item.content:encoded:
Borderlands 4’s release date is screeching into sight and is set to be one of the biggest releases in 2025, and we’ve got all the details you need.

Our hands-on preview of Borderlands 4 at Gamescom raised our excitement levels for the title, which comes a whopping six years after the previous entry in the series landed, and there’s plenty to take in, with 30 billion guns featured.

If you’re looking to lock in for release, perhaps calling in sick from work for the day, we’ve got all the crucial release datte and start times information you need.

When is Borderlands 4 Coming Out?

September 12 is the official release date for Borderlands 4 on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC, with Nintendo Switch 2 players having to wait a while longer until October 3.

With the Borderlands 4 release date now locked in and on the horizon, there shouldn’t be any changes to the release date. Gearbox has already made the rather unusual move of bringing the Borderlands 4 release date forward, with CEO Randy Pitchford then denying the decision had anything to do with Grand Theft Auto 6.

The release date was brought forward by “confidence in the game and development trajectory,” giving fans a nice early bonus. As mentioned, however, Switch 2 players have a little while longer to wait.

Borderlands 4 Start Times

Borderlands 4’s official start times are yet to be announced, but listings on the PlayStation store suggest it will be available a midnight regionally.

The UK PlayStation Store and Australian PlayStation Store both have midnight in their respective time zones, while the US PlayStation Store has a midnight release in Eastern Time stated—though it’s unclear whether this means those in other US time zones will gain access at the same moment.

A midnight regional release would also open the door for players to gain earlier access by switching their time zone, which is much easier to do on Xbox Series X|S than it is on PlayStation. However, we won’t know for sure if this is possible until the release times are confirmed.

For easier viewing, the table below shows the release times in popular time zones. Please remember that these are subject to change; we’ll be sure to keep them updated.

item.title: Under Par Golf Architect HANDS-ON Preview: A Golf Tycoon Simulator Scoring More Birdies Than Bogeys
item.content:encoded:
Gamescom 2025 was my first hands-on with Under Par Golf Architect. A fully golf-centric tycoon simulator where you control all aspects of golf course management. As a huge golf fan, this was right up my street. It’s the perfect hybrid of golf sim and golf creation aspects, it irons out any doubts I had, you should putt this on your wishlist if you’re a golf fan, and you wood be doing yourself a disservice if you didn’t.

It feels apt that I’m writing this as the 2025 Tour Championship has concluded to wrap up the FedEx Cup. Whereas everyone was waiting for the monolithic presence of Scottie Scheffler or Rory McIlroy to take home the richest prize on the PGA Tour, it was a relative underdog in Tommy Fleetwood who comfortably prevailed.

In this scenario, EA Sports PGA Tour and 2K’s PGA Tour are Scottie and Rory, and Under Par Golf Architect is rightly Tommy.

Makes The Complexities of a Golf Complex Rather Simple

I love playing real golf, and I also can’t get enough of simulated golf, where I can immerse myself in a virtual world to pretend I’m actually good at golf and escape my real-world inadequacies and lack of talent. From the 00s Tiger Woods games to EA Sports PGA Tour and HB Studios’ decade-long golf-game efforts, I’ll play everything.

So it was intriguing to hear about Under Par Golf Architect. I can’t think of a dedicated golf sim game on this macro level since Sid Meier’s SimGolf in 2002. I had to see it for myself at Gamescom 2025. A private setup gave me a hands-on look and learning experience. Its premise is similar to any other ‘tycoon’ game: Micromanage every aspect of a golf course’s infrastructure.

You build a golf course in a plot of land, surround it with amenities to increase public satisfaction and optimize consumption of the facilities, appease your patrons, earn lots of money, and maximize customer enjoyment. You do this by tweaking the golf course to adhere to the golfer’s feedback, ensuring your workforce is on top of course maintenance, and various other factors. I visibly giggled every time I saw raccoons feeding on the course’s rubbish if left untidied for too long.

I quickly whipped up a nice little brute of a Par 3 surrounded by water, offering a horrendously undulating green. The controls were easy enough to execute my vision, and the hole design seemed funny to me. However, I quickly realized the novelty would soon be met with the hostility and incredulity of visitors—you need to be smart and channel your inner Pete Dye or Alister Mackenzie.

I exhaled a slight “ooo” when Broken Arms Games CEO Yves Hohler showed me what was essentially an AI data model you can use to test your golf holes. It takes into account High, Mid, Low, and Scratch Handicappers and simulates how they’d all play the hole. It gives you useful insight into where they’re landing their shots—or where the less-talented of us would inexplicably be spraying and praying our golf ball around the property.

This foresight and knowledge can help you make vital changes to the course. But don’t make the course too easy, or your more experienced golfers will scoff and leave in search of a challenge. On the contrary, you need to be mindful about not making every hole narrow, hazard-filled, and with green speeds even Augusta National would consider a glass-like menace.

Under Par is a single-player tycoon sim with multiple levels and biomes arriving at launch. I’ve been assured that the playing aspect was added in response to community feedback and is there if you fancy a quick knockabout. The business and simulation principles are where the game’s priorities lie. If you find PGA Tour 2K’s course creator to be a bit advanced, time-consuming, or cumbersome, I think you’ll really enjoy this.

A lot of love has gone into making Under Par Golf Architect. Time will tell if it’s a bona fide major winner, but I think it’s earned its tour card and is ready to see if its vision can become par for the course.

Even non-golf fans will find plenty to love about Under Park Golf Architect. The Insider Gaming forum is the perfect place to discuss your love of golf or other tycoon games, including the Two Point series or Jurassic World Evolution.

item.title: Is Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater on Xbox Game Pass?
item.content:encoded:
Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater is bringing the neglected franchise back to life after a few years of dormancy, and we’ve got all the details on whether the title is available through Game Pass.

Releasing on August 28, the full achievement list for Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater shows details of the adventure that lies ahead of Solid Snake, though confirmation that the title doesn’t feature crossplay is a blow.

If you’re on the fence about purchasing Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater and are wondering if it will be included in a Game Pass subscription, we’ve got all the details.

No, Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater will not be available through an Xbox Game Pass subscription when it launches on August 28th.

Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater is not a first-party Xbox title, which would result in automatic inclusion in the service, and there has not been any announcement of it landing on the service. As such, it won’t be included.

Microsoft has already announced the second wave of August titles coming to Game Pass, covering until the end of the month, and Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater did not feature. If it was, it would’ve been one of the highlights of the service, receiving a lot of attention.

Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater is unlikely to come to the Xbox Game Pass catalog in the future, and any inclusion would surely be quite far away.

Virtuos, co-developer of Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater alongside Konami, has released several titles on the Game Pass service in the past, though the final decision with this title will more than likely fall upon Konami.

Konami’s publishing on Xbox is much more limited, and their titles barely ever feature in the Game Pass catalog, so it seems unlikely that Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater will make an appearance in the library anytime soon. However, stranger things have happened.

If you do want to play Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater on Xbox, the best approach is to purchase the game for launch.
